reviewText:
An amazing series of exploratative puzzles, and one of the best uses of design space that I can recall.

The game itself is difficult to explain.  Its a first person wasd + mouse control scheme with only 4 additional forms of input.  Fire, jump, restart, and exit.  These functions change slightly from level to level.  Sometimes you might not be able to jump, sometimes you might be able to fly, sometimes your fire button does... something entirely different.

There is very little in the sense of hints (usually you have the name of a level and a single short sentence with which to build your guesses).  This can be a boon or a curse depending on how quickly you pick up the goal of a stage.

The game is somewhat simplistic visually, but handles its setting and theme very well.  With its otherwordly sound track, constant visual tricks, and a very novel approach to death (there technically isn't any), I felt very much like some sort of nethermancer seeking to accumulate souls for whatever purpose a nethermancer soul searches.

I very much suggest purchasing this game, I've already bought several copies for friends.  It's a game you don't want to miss.

reviewText:
What is this? Where am I? What do I have to do?

If you want to buy this game you will likely ask this and similar questions very soon. This is by far the weirdest, best, hardest puzzle game I played.
If you look for AAA graphics and smooth textures you should buy something else. But if you are looking for a challenge and hate it to be constantly annoyed by a tutorial or other guide mechanics you will have much fun.

So far I only managed to solve a few of the puzzles, some of which I know how they might work, but were not able to finish it due to the lack of skill I have ;) Some I just not know what I have to do, but I will try and try and try.

+ many puzzles
+ challenging
+ easy controls (WASD + Mouse + Space)

- options sometimes reset.
- display bugs with fullscreen/no fullscreen switch
- addicting

Disclaimer: I got a free key to test this game.

reviewText: I intend to go back and revise this review once I've completed a bigger portion of the game.\n\nThe primary appeal of this game is that you don't really get any instructions. There isn't a tutorial. The faint text clues" you see are vague and often irrelevant. You're dropped into a starter level to get a hands-on grasp of the controls

voteText: but each is technically an isolated instance that must be deciphered. You don't know whether you're just getting from A to B
votesHelpful: etc. until you try it and find out.\n\nIt's a weird game
votesTotal: but if you are interested in exploration and puzzle-solving with a heavy emphasis on trial and error
votesFunny: this is worth a try.\n\nThe controls are very straightforward: move
column16: and click (which usually functions as "shoot") the platforming is important
column17: but it's in service of solving the puzzles.\n\nThere is a very ominous aesthetic at work. The sights and sounds seem designed to keep you on edge. Some of the levels are calm and quite beautiful

reviewText:
This game is amazing. It has a really cool abstract art style and level design. It's not your average first-person puzzle platformer.

So far, I've beaten the first set of levels at least enough to move on to the next set of levels and I have to say the levels are excellently crafted and each one is unique with challenging puzzles that the player must overcome. It also feels really satisfying when you beat a level you've been stuck on or if you finally understand what you have to do to complete a puzzle.

The people who are raging at this game don't actually grasp the real meaning of this game. It is a puzzle game and requires thinking and time to play. That is what a puzzle game is.

Sure the game has a few flaws and some of the levels are a little bit vague but I think that's what the creator wanted. The levels are supposed to be very difficult and abstract.

Overall this game deserves more respect considering it is a truly unique indie puzzle game that gives you an amazing experience. 4.5/5 stars!

reviewText:
The product's description is not joking. This is a really tough puzzle game. I'd even call it puzzle-horror due to how unsettling the surreal landscape is.
This is a game for people who like beating a level after smashing their heads against it fifteen times in a row. Puzzles start by giving you a vague hint, and then sending you on your way. You only have three tools, your space bar to jump (usually), your LMB to Emit and capture souls (usually) and your RMB which resets the level. Each level has different rules, and you need to understand them before you can win. The levels are purposefully made to be quite short, though some puzzles require some finesse and can feel longer as a result.

I am not kidding when I say this game's tough. If you start up the game and go wow I barely beat that level on World 1!" don't feel discouraged. Even the first few worlds are quite challening and you should be proud of yourself that you were up for the task.

Atmosphere-wise
date: this is a game for people who wished The Witness was a bit more like OFF. The game uses a lot of filters and effects
recommended: which can turn off some people
hoursPlayed: but they eventually grew on me.\n\nI will say right away that this game is not for everyone. The visual effects can be a bit much at times
voteText: so play the demo to make sure they don't make you sick. Some of them get really
votesHelpful: I don't regret buying Ilamentia. I have not finished it
votesTotal: but I got about 60-70% of the puzzles. I still play it from time to time to try and crack a few more puzzles. It's always easy to pick up

reviewText:
What?

I don't...

What.

Illamentia is an obscure title almost akin to the likes of Yume Nikki or Dreaming Sara in the sense that you have to try to understand the things around you, however where the game differs is not only in its' art style, but in the puzzle-style gameplay presented to you. Picture this: You see a giant tower-like object, and you can shoot cubes around it to change their color. The ground under you is completely reflective, as you pace around for a little bit, you notice the reflection of the cubes represents what their color should be in the overhead world. It's simple, not too complicated, but makes for some interesting concepts at times when the puzzles get a bit more difficult. The jumping puzzle was awful, don't even get me started on that, but i'll let it slide considering it's kind of a 3d platformer in a way as well.

If you like weird games, and 3d platformers, you just might get a decent kick out of it, hell I liked it enough to play for about 5 hours, so hey, give it a try if it looks like something that interests you.

reviewText: The game is fairly random, which is my attribution as to why it's difficult.  A set of levels appears to have a common art theme, but not a common gameplay theme.\n\nMany puzzle games introduce a mechanic and build upon it, this game does not do that in a conventional manner.   I'm sure the devs put a lot of time into the game since there are new mechanics in almost every level, but the game doesn't really have a coherent presentation.  Most levels I wouldn't call what I did solving a puzzle"
date: more just wandering around or trying things randomly until the game progressed.  Was there a mechanic involved to progress? Yes. Was there any depth to that mechanic? Not usually.\n\nThat said
recommended: I only played through the first two worlds.  Chances are that the mechanics do build up
hoursPlayed: as no set of devs can come up with a hundred different mechanics.  But the organization of levels is rather frustrating.  It's like taking a person and tossing them into a workshop and telling them to use one tool
voteText: then some other tool entirely. You don't ever develop your skill with one tool because you simply don't get the opportunity to become familiar with it.\n\nThe art is pretty cool.  I don't really care for the soul faces and the 'death' style screen/enemies and actually think they don't fit the game so much (Could just be abstract objects instead)
helpfulPercent: but the rest of the environments are cool looking and provide good ambiance.\n\nOverall it's the kind of game that doesn't make me feel compelled to continue playing due to the disjointness of the puzzles.  It's like finishing the sudoku in the newspaper and then deciding that maybe later you'll come back to doing the crossword and maybe later after that you'll do the word search

reviewText:
I hate this game. I like this game. I definitely don't love it, though. But that's fine, because it hates me too.

What is Ilamentia? A first-person game where you:
1. Solve puzzles
2. Shoot stuff
3. Platform

But I wouldn't call it a first-person puzzle platformer FPS because that isn't really accurate. Sometimes you do all at once. Sometimes you do only one or two.

The point of the game, really, is that each level plays by its own rules. Practically every level is something unique. The game never really gets repetitive because diversity is its strength.

Diversity is also its weakness, however, since there's plenty of bad ideas mixed in with the good ones. Some levels have way-too-tight platforming for the game engine, some levels have gimmicks mostly focused on obscuring vision, some levels have puzzles too obscure to figure out from the brief hint given at the start of the level. There's also a lot of good platforming and some really clever puzzles. But you can't have the good stuff without the bad stuff too, so the game can go from enjoyable to frustrating at a moment's notice. The graphic style, overall, isn't very friendly either, and the effects in the last world especially are just waaaay too much.

I would say I'm glad I played it, but it's not something I'm rushing off to show others, and there's a lot of bad things to be said about the game too. Consider this on the low end of posititve, I'd put it in the meh" category if it existed though."
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Now this game is what you might call a hidden gem. I'd never heard or seen anything about this game anywhere before. From the trailer Ilamentia looks a bit naff to be honest, a game from the 90s, but I took a gamble on it as it was on sale and I needed to scratch the itch The Talos Principle left.

There is no real story to speak of. All you get are little poetic sentences that sometimes show themselves randomly and they seem to be describing a narrative of sorts. But you shouldn't go in expecting a Talos Principle epiphany.

The game is divided into lots of small levels. You pick a level and you then have to activate little pink screaming faces to make the exit appear which you must then get to. The brilliance of the game is how you activte the faces is very different for every level. In one level you may have to light or arrange blocks in a specific order, or you might have to explore a maze, or you might have to decypher meaning from weird signs, or you might have to answer a crafty riddle, or you might just have to run away from weird scary faces over an obstacle course. You never know what the hell you will find when entering a new level and that's the game's greatest asset.

I was much more of a fan of the levels involving puzzles rather than the platforming segments, but thankfully it seems none of the levels are locked so you can focus on just playing the levels you like and ignore the rest. The game also doesn't tell you how the level works, you have to discover it out for yourself, but there are usually little hints, like a platform will light up once you stand on it. At times this can feel great as you figure out the new mechanics and their purpose but there was also plenty of times where I felt lost and had to come back to later.

I couldn't find any meaningful sense of progression aside from a tick for completing the level and Steam's achievements. I would like to see more of a reward, such as hidden levels or a hidden story.

The price seems a little on the high side for when you take into account there's no story and the graphics are dated, so I'd recommend getting it when it's on sale. If you're a fan of FPS puzzles games then this is an insta-buy for your collection.

reviewText:
My initial review was rather negative as I felt the game came off too pretencious while being too confusing for your average gamer. It didn't explain much and did not do great in introduction of the puzzles.

Now, a year later after my first impression the game been updated with quite a few fixes. I can't say it improved a lot in terms of clarity, but it certainly been adressed to some degree by the developer, which is a positive thing. I personally still feel that it is a bit on the confusing side, but at this point I would shrug it off to this not being being my type of thing as I can certainly see its abstract appeal.

Some of the puzzles are still somewhat abstract to figure out. Some are logically easy, some are pretty hard leaving you wondering wtf you are supposed to do. Some people like that, and this is a game for them. I am personally on the neutral now, but it deserves a recommendation just because developer keeps updating the game and listening to the feedback.

0/10.

This game seems prone to giving me a headache. The screenwaving was making me feel sick, so I turned that off. But the transparent flashing colours and faces it seems can't be turned off.

If I was epileptic, I would have had a seizure the flashing is that bad. I have my screen brightness all the way down and it's still terrible.

Not to mention, punishing a player by means of flashing lights is terrible motiviation. A simple black screen of you're doing the wrong thing" would have sufficed as opposed to microwaving the insides of my eyeballs.

I'm sure the puzzles are great
recommended: but the effervescent colours were just too much to deal with."

reviewText:
Ilamentia is an interesting gem that is unlike any other game I've played.

Visually it lacks the polish seen in modern games, but a lot of creativity has gone into the very differing aesthetics for each of the hub areas. The music is also very atmospheric and creepy which suits the game well. That creativity is even more startling when it comes to the gameplay, with every level it seems focusing on something totally different. The biggest challenge is simply figuring out how the levels work, so you need a certain level of experimental skill to even begin to solve them. There is a hint when you enter a level but it's often cryptic, and there were a number of levels where I just had to give up and look at one of the guides to figure out what to do. Some levels then either have a logic based puzzle or are an obstacle course. I wasn't a fan of the obstacle courses, it seems a lot of which focus on platforming, but there are a great many levels and the level selection is open so I could safely focus on the more puzzle orientated levels ignoring those I didn't like.

If you're a fan of first person puzzle games that require inventive logic to solve then I'd recommend this game. Though bear in mind that many levels use varying levels of action"
date: such as shooting floating faces that come toward you
recommended: or platforming.\n\nI'd recommend you wait for it to go on sale too
hoursPlayed: since the visual level of polish isn't quite what I expect from a modern game."
voteText: December 19, 2015

reviewText: It's a solid first person puzzler and there aren't many of those around so here's my support for more. Godspeed devs.

reviewText: I'd call this more of a discovery game than a puzzle game. It seems like most of the game is about figuring out how the individual levels mechanically work, of which there's a lot of variety in the gameplay interactions, then you have the added challenge of putting that knowledge into action to reach the exit. I'd recommend it if you're into games like Antichamber where the puzzles are based on creative exploration of the world rather than hardcore logic puzzles. Sadly there aren't many inventive games out there like this which is a shame, so I hope the developers make a sequel that smooths over some of the negatives, like the dated graphics.
